title: Netflix's Migration to Microservices
summary: How Netflix migrated from a monolithic architecture to microservices to achieve massive scale.
content:
Case Study: Netflix Microservices

By 2008, Netflix had grown to millions of subscribers but their monolithic architecture struggled to scale. A database corruption incident prompted a complete rethink of their infrastructure strategy.

The Migration

Netflix gradually decomposed their monolith into hundreds of independent microservices. Each team owned their service end-to-end, enabling independent deployment and scaling. They also moved entirely to AWS.

Engineering Innovations

Netflix developed tools like Hystrix (circuit breaker), Zuul (API gateway), and Eureka (service discovery) — many of which they open-sourced. Chaos Monkey proactively tested resilience by randomly terminating production instances.

Key Learnings

Microservices enable scale but add operational complexity. Strong DevOps culture and tooling are prerequisites. Incremental migration is safer than a big-bang rewrite.
